items.title: Test failures on Python 3.9
items.body:
Running the tests on Python 3.9 make two test cases fail.

ERROR: test_unpack_composite (test_umsgpack.TestUmsgpack)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/test_umsgpack.py", line 439, in test_unpack_composite
    self.assertEqual(umsgpack.unpackb(data), obj)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 1019, in _unpackb3
    return _unpack(io.BytesIO(s), options)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 833, in _unpack
    return _unpack_dispatch_table[code](code, fp, options)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 813, in _unpack_map
    elif not isinstance(k, collections.Hashable):
AttributeError: module 'collections' has no attribute 'Hashable'

ERROR: test_unpack_exceptions (test_umsgpack.TestUmsgpack)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/test_umsgpack.py", line 446, in test_unpack_exceptions
    umsgpack.unpackb(data)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 1019, in _unpackb3
    return _unpack(io.BytesIO(s), options)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 833, in _unpack
    return _unpack_dispatch_table[code](code, fp, options)
  File "/builddir/build/BUILD/u-msgpack-python-2.5.0/umsgpack.py", line 813, in _unpack_map
    elif not isinstance(k, collections.Hashable):
AttributeError: module 'collections' has no attribute 'Hashable'

This is due to the classes from collections.abc not being exposed anymore through the collections module: https://docs.python.org/3.9/whatsnew/3.9.html#removed

In that case `Hashable` needs to be imported from `collections.abc`

items.title: Pack/Unpack Tuple
items.body:
Hello, 
Would it be possible to pack and unpack a `tuple`? Right now it packs as an `array`, and unpacks it always as a `list`. 
Maybe there could be two different codes for `Tuple` and `List`, instead of a single `array`?

items.title: msgpack deprecating encoding option
items.body:
Warning in shell:
```
DeprecationWarning: encoding is deprecated, Use raw=False instead.
    return msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')
```

Offical notes:
https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-python#deprecating-encoding-option

the option will be removed when msgpack-python 1.0 released.

items.title: _read_except() throws InsufficientDataException for short reads
items.body:
When reading from files, the network, etc. there's no guarantee that `read(n)` returns `n` bytes so you need to keep calling `read()` until you get all the data.

I will send a PR with a test case and proposed fix.

items.title: Add default support for timestamp types
items.body: It would be nice if the new timestamp extension could be used without needing to provide an exthook for it. Suggested deserialization would be as the result of `datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp`

items.title: tar ball on pypi
items.body: Is it possible to also release the tar-ball on pypi (this is the standard location for tar-balls for packages in opensuse for example)? For 2.5.0 the tar-ball seems to be missing.  Thanks!

items.title: pack_ext_handler/unpack_ext_handler are not endian aware
items.body:
HI,

pack_ext_handler/unpack_ext_handler break on big-endian platforms like ppc and s390,
so the testcases for these functions fail on all big-endian platforms as they assume little-endian

items.title: UnsupportedTypeException: unsupported type: <type 'set'>
items.body:
UnsupportedTypeException: unsupported type: <type 'set'>

```
EXT_HANDLERS={
    datetime.datetime: lambda obj: umsgpack.Ext(0x40, obj.strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ').encode()),
    datetime.date: lambda obj: umsgpack.Ext(0x50, obj.strftime('%Y-%m-%d').encode()),
    datetime.timedelta: lambda obj: umsgpack.Ext(0x60, str(obj)),
    decimal.Decimal: lambda obj: umsgpack.Ext(0x70, str(obj)),
    set: lambda obj: umsgpack.Ext(0x80, str(obj)),
}
```

items.title: Allow to force
items.body: I would like to be able to force float serialization to 4-bytes floats rather than 8-bytes doubles. Spontaneously I'd do that by adding an option `single_float=<bool>` to `pack`. Would you be interested by such a pull request, and would you prefer another way to provide this feature?

items.title: Missing datetime.datetime serializer
items.body: Can we add this in? I saw this is already implemented in msgpack. Even for JSON, I can use a different sterilizer for datetimes.

items.title: LICENSE file is missing in tar.gz on PyPi
items.body:
Could you add this file in your next release?

Thanks.

items.title: Add Ext type hook support
items.body: Add Ext type hook support via registration or argument for packing and unpacking calls.

items.title: test_umsgpack.py missing from tarball
items.body:
test_umsgpack.py is missing from the tarball on pypi.

It would be nice if it was included to be able to test releases (e.g. when building packages for distributions) and not just the git version

items.title: msgpack not unpack unicode string correclty - should be unicode but is str
items.body:
It leads to problems since after such conversion - us.encode() is valid but decoded.encode() is invalid ('utf-8' - python 2.7.x). Type should be not changed during serialization.

```
import msgpack

us = u'Hello World!'
s = us.encode()

encoded = msgpack.packb(us)
decoded = msgpack.unpackb(encoded)

print type(us), type(decoded)

encoded = msgpack.packb(s)
decoded = msgpack.unpackb(encoded)

print type(s), type(decoded)
```

items.title: test fails occaisonally in TestUmsgpack.test_pack_composite
items.body:
The issue is that the hash can change ocaisonally, causing the order to be different (and therefore the bytes to be different).

I think a possible solution is to use `collections.OrderedDict`

items.title: Add option for ordered dictionaries
items.body: MessagePack's maps are an ordered sequence, so add an library option to deserialize maps into an OrderedDict() instead of a plain dict, to better reflect the serialized content.

items.title: use xrange for python2
items.body:
you use range(length) at some places where length could be 2^32-1.

in python2 that call returns a LIST with that number of elements. rather use xrange for python2.
for python3, "range" behaves like "xrange" in python2, thus no problem there.

items.title: umsgpack can't unpack python dicts with tuple keys
items.body:
e.g., for a python dict like:
a = {(1, 2): 3}
it is ok to do umsgpack.pack(a), but get UnhashableKeyException when doing unpack.

The cause is when packing, tuples become lists, but lists can't be a dict key.
But we can safely assume when we see a list as a dict key, it was a tuple at the moment it was serialized. So maybe we can just do

if isinstance(k, list):
    k = tuple(k)

and then all the checkings (around line 549)

items.title: use constants instead of calculations
items.body: lots of inline calculations which seem extraneous for size constants.. better to just use constants as ref

items.title: Double-byte (or larger) UTF-8 strings are encoded with the wrong size.
items.body:
Hello,

 Thanks for your work on this, it's been most useful for me. 

 I have encountered one error and fixed it, so I'm passing it on to see if you agree it's an error, and if it needs inclusion as a revision.

 Currently I'm moving contact data between programs, and it's crashing on the decode of some French names. 

 The problem is in _pack_string. It's calculating the length of the string before it's encoded to UTF-8.

 I think you must encode the string before you find the length of it, as some characters need to encode as double-byte or longer.

 An example would be the French name Allagbe, or the French word precedent , where the 'e' is with Acute (http://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/e9/index.htm)

 Python's encoder makes this b'Allagb\xc3\xa9', which is one byte longer than than the original string. 

 u-msgpack encodes this as b'\xa7Allagb\xc3\xa9'  - notice how it's only 7 bytes long - it's trimming the \xa9 char from the msgpack. 

 When you feed this trimmed string through a .decode('utf-8') method, you'll crash with a python error : 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 6: unexpected end of data

 The solution is to encode to UTF-8 before calculating the string length, as detailed below:

def _pack_string(x):
 x = x.encode('utf-8')
    if len(x) <= 31:
        return struct.pack("B", 0xa0 | len(x)) + x
    elif len(x) <= 2**8-1:
        return b"\xd9" + struct.pack("B", len(x)) + x
    elif len(x) <= 2**16-1:
        return b"\xda" + struct.pack(">H", len(x)) + x
    elif len(x) <= 2**32-1:
        return b"\xdb" + struct.pack(">I", len(x)) + x
    else:
        raise UnsupportedTypeException("huge string")

With this patch in place, I am able to pass all French names in u-msgpack without error. 

-end-

items.title: umsgpack.packb() problem in python2.6
items.body:
I checked packing process of 
umsgpack for python2.6 and python3.3.

for ["a","b"]
expected packed value is:
--> 0x91 0xa0 0x61 0xa0 0x62
from the messagepack speficication.
("a" = 0x61, "b" = 0x62)

The results from umsgpack are as follows:
The output from pytho3.3 may be OK,
but the output from python2.6 seems to be apparently incorrect.
Is it possible to fix this difference?

python2.6 : 
0x92 0xc4 0x1 0x61 0xc4 0x1 0x62

python3.3 :
0x92 0xa1 0x61 0xa1 0x62

I asked this because I had trouble to use this packed results
for python2.6 in other messagepack program in C library.
(For python3.3, it was OK though)

Thank you for your help.

Takahiro Matsumoto

---->
- used check program, b.py

--->
import umsgpack

objectList = ["a","b"]
packed     = umsgpack.packb(objectList)
print("#len = %d" % len(packed))
for v in packed:
    try:
        print("0x%x" % ord(v))  # case for python2.6
    except:
        print("0x%x" % int(v))  # case for python3.3
<---
- output from python2.6 and python3.3

matumot@test[68]_%python2.6 b.py
# len = 7

0x92
0xc4
0x1
0x61
0xc4
0x1
0x62

matumot@test[69]_%python3.3 b.py
# len = 5

0x92
0xa1
0x61
0xa1
0x62
- reference from message pack specification

fixarray stores an array whose length is upto 15 elements:
+--------+~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~+
|1001XXXX|    N objects    |
+--------+~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~+

fixstr stores a byte array whose length is upto 31 bytes:
+--------+========+
|101XXXXX|  data  |
+--------+========+

items.title: What's the difference between this and the `msgpack-python`?
items.body:
Another repo here: https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack-python

While the official site recommend this `u-msgpack-python`, I'm a little confused.

Both implemented in pure python and both support the latest msgpack 2.0 and both support python2/3.

So what's the difference?

items.title: Add Raw 16 / Raw 32 Serializer Compatibility Mode
items.body: MessagePack spec dictates that serializers should provide a compatibility mode that doesn't use str8 or bin.

items.title: Provide access to bytes for invalid UTF-8 strings
items.body: MessagePack spec dictates that deserializers should provide access to original bytes of invalid UTF-8 strings.
